{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2963429,"name":"Smtopps","username":"Smtopps","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/smtopps/{size}/166758_2.png","created_at":"2021-07-29T20:01:50.522Z","cooked":"

Our team has made several custom elevators over the past years and we are looking to expand our options using the telescoping/nested design and use 3D printing to help.

image62×803 5.06 KB
image138×796 11.4 KB

image713×769 53.5 KB
image874×734 78.9 KB

image733×697 52.2 KB
image860×711 59.3 KB

Onshape CAD: Onshape

This design is a work in progress so some functionality is not yet in the design. It uses the 1.97lbs Conforce springs from Vulcan which comes in the KOP and the design follows their design guide. I plan on changing the springs based on weight but i needed a starting point. It currently does not have a way to attach a pulling rope to retract it.

Questions:

  1. Is there a factor of safety or something I should consider to ensure the springs will raise the column. Example: if the column weights the exact same as the spring is supposed to support then I assume it will not lift it so I should need the spring to lift a certain amount more than the mechanism weights.
  2. What material would be best to print this out of. We have a new markforged onyx one which I like the print quality and strength but I am worried the material might not be as low friction or even abrasive. Otherwise we have a fusion3 printer which prints the typical wide variety of materials.
  3. What is the best way to mount/attach the top sliders which hold the springs. I was thinking maybe a snap fit would work. I would prefer to stay away from epoxy/glue.
  4. Are springs required on both sides to balance the force on the column. I know I could put springs on both sides if I need more force but not more length.

iew_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/3d-printing-telescoping-nested-elevator-questions/395287/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":2963430,"name":"Ricky Marcus","username":"RickyRobot","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/e19adc/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-07-29T20:14:15.088Z","cooked":"

  1. Yes you need it to be greater. Not only will there be friction you need to overcome, but you will need greater force to lift it more quickly. Do some back of the envelope math and double it.

  2. I would use onyx and plan on lining with a thin low friction tape for your bearing surfaces.

  3. Glue or screws if you can fit them. Snaps seem like more headache than they’re worth.

  4. It would be nice. Things not pulled evenly tend to bind. But you won’t know until you try.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2021-07-29T20:14:15.088Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":179,"readers_count":178,"score":40.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":395287,"topic_slug":"3d-printing-telescoping-nested-elevator-questions","display_username":"Ricky Marcus","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":30577,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/3d-printing-telescoping-nested-elevator-questions/395287/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2963431,"name":"Clayton Ramsey","username":"ClayTownR","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/claytownr/{size}/158381_2.png","created_at":"2021-07-29T20:18:57.246Z","cooked":"
Smtopps:

Is there a factor of safety or something I should consider to ensure the springs will raise the column

I would probably recommend having a spring for about 2x the weight of the climber assembly. I would also recommend buying a few springs of differing weights and designing such that you can easily swap between them, in case you change your mind. The trade-off here is that more force on the spring brings the climber up faster, but raises the load when bringing it back down.

Smtopps:

What is the best way to mount/attach the top sliders which hold the springs.

You might be able to get away with a snap fit, but it would be pretty difficult. Perhaps cutting some grooves to allow the pieces to flex somewhat as you put them on. Make sure to measure your extrusions with calipers and sizing the caps to fit, since the tubes may be off from nominal by enough to ruin your fits.

Smtopps:

Are springs required on both sides to balance the force on the column.

No. The aspect ratio of this kind of climber is very large, so the sideways forces tend to be low on the way up.

Some other considerations:

  • Measure the exact size of your extrusions with calipers. I can’t stress this enough - the nominal sizing could be off enough to ruin everything.
  • Leave at least .005" or so of clearance on every side for a smooth slip fit. If you use low-friction tape, make sure to include the thickness of that in your gaps. I noticed that everything in your current CAD is sized to be exactly nominal - this will bind in real life.
  • Trim down the outside corners of your “moving” bearings - we found that those tended to bind most often, so chamfering or filleting them helped a lot
  • Likewise, cut out the inside corners on your “fixed” bearings, for much the same reason.
  • Add a chamfer on the edges sliding against a wall so there isn’t something sharp for them to bind on.
  • Pay some attention to how you’re going to mount the entire assembly to the rest of the robot. If you put a big enough cutout on your first-stage moving bearing, you will have enough room for rivnuts.

I planed on going back through the model and adding the tolerance to the parts. I am a mentor and will ultimately use this to teach students if I am happy with what I learned from this model. We also tend to use tubing that already has rounded corners so I will change that depending on what route we go.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2021-07-29T20:26:43.476Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":143,"readers_count":142,"score":33.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":395287,"topic_slug":"3d-printing-telescoping-nested-elevator-questions","display_username":"Smtopps","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":28741,"username":"ClayTownR","name":"Clayton Ramsey","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/claytownr/{size}/158381_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":33408,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/3d-printing-telescoping-nested-elevator-questions/395287/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2963433,"name":"Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)","username":"ngreen","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ngreen/{size}/264478_2.png","created_at":"2021-07-29T20:39:16.836Z","cooked":"
Smtopps:

Are springs required on both sides to balance the force on the column. I know I could put springs on both sides if I need more force but not more length.

I’d recommend both sides (two springs) if you can do it. We did one and it would bind. Not our only reason, but it seemed that going with springs on both sides was used by teams that climbed reliably. There might be some examples of doing single sided well out there, I don’t have any to share, but there are many doing dual sided springs. Not having it come out or get stuck is frustrating, and while single sided should work, I’d rather overdo it to avoid that.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2021-07-29T20:39:16.836Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":146,"readers_count":145,"score":34.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":395287,"topic_slug":"3d-printing-telescoping-nested-elevator-questions","display_username":"Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":2695,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/3d-printing-telescoping-nested-elevator-questions/395287/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2963434,"name":"Mark Wasserman","username":"Mark_Wasserman","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mark_wasserman/{size}/9677_2.png","created_at":"2021-07-29T20:48:29.465Z","cooked":"

Delrin or nylon would be preferred but onyx on aluminum should be fine especially since there isn’t an extreme load on the sliding surfaces. As others have indicated, the secret is make sure you have enough spring to overcome any drag especially as things get used and worn out or worn in.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2021-07-29T20:48:29.465Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":146,"readers_count":145,"score":44.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":395287,"topic_slug":"3d-printing-telescoping-nested-elevator-questions","display_username":"Mark Wasserman","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":30473,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Not fast swerve, but good swerve driven quickly"},"post_url":"/t/3d-printing-telescoping-nested-elevator-questions/395287/6","custom_user_title":"Not fast swerve, but good swerve driven quickly","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2963435,"name":"wgorgen","username":"wgorgen","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/wgorgen/{size}/10106_2.png","created_at":"2021-07-29T21:14:13.111Z","cooked":"

I would recommend using bearings on the bottom of each stage rather than trying to manage the friction of a sliding mechanism. With 3D printed caps, it should be relatively easy to design a cap that can hold bearings.

Take a look at this post from Simbotics describing their 2020 telescoping arm

Note that they have made their CAD models public so you can poke around and see how they implemented other details of their design of that arm.
